transcript:
Patient: I can't really think of any evidence that I'm a bad friend. I mean, I do try to be there for my friends when I can. And I've been going through a tough time lately, so it's understandable that I might need to cancel sometimes.

Therapist: That's a great point, Jamie. The fact that you're aware of your friends' needs and you try to be there for them is evidence that you are a good friend. And you're right, going through a tough time can make it harder to be as present as you'd like to be. That doesn't make you a bad friend, it just makes you human.

What about the second thought: "I'm always letting people down." Is there evidence that this is true?

Patient: I guess I have let people down before, like when I cancel plans. But I don't do it all the time. And I've been working on communicating better when I'm struggling, so my friends know what's going on with me.

Therapist: Exactly. It's not accurate to say that you always let people down. And the fact that you're working on communicating more openly with your friends shows that you're making an effort to be there for them in the ways that you can.

Let's look at the third thought: "My friend must be so annoyed with me." What evidence do you have for this thought?

Patient: Well, I don't actually know how my friend feels. I assumed they were annoyed, but they didn't say that. And they know I've been having a hard time, so they might actually be understanding about it.

Therapist: That's a really important insight, Jamie. We often assume that we know what other people are thinking, but the truth is, we don't. And assuming the worst can lead to a lot of unnecessary distress.

Finally, let's consider the fourth thought: "I'm never going to have close friendships if I keep doing this." What do you think about this one?

Patient: I guess that's kind of extreme. I mean, I do have close friendships, even though I struggle sometimes. And like we talked about before, having depression doesn't mean I'll never be able to have the kind of relationships I want.

Therapist: Absolutely. Depression can make relationships more challenging, but it doesn't mean you're doomed to be alone forever. You have the skills and the capacity to build and maintain close friendships, even if it takes some extra effort and understanding sometimes.

Now that we've looked at the evidence for and against these thoughts, let's see if we can come up with some more balanced and helpful thoughts to replace them with. What's a more accurate and compassionate way to think about this situation?

Patient: I guess I could tell myself something like "I'm doing the best I can right now, and that's enough. My friends care about me and understand that I'm going through a tough time. One canceled plan doesn't define our friendship."

Therapist: That's a wonderful reframe, Jamie. It acknowledges the reality of the situation while also offering yourself some kindness and understanding. And it recognizes that your friends are likely to be more understanding than you might assume.

How do you feel when you think about the situation in this new way?

Patient: I feel a lot better, actually. Less guilty and more hopeful. It's a relief to realize that one setback doesn't mean everything is ruined.

Therapist: That's great to hear, Jamie. Reframing our thoughts in a more balanced and compassionate way can have a big impact on how we feel. And it can help us move forward in a more productive and positive way.

We're getting close to the end of our session today. Before we wrap up, I want to check in on how you're feeling and see if there's anything else you'd like to discuss.

Patient: I'm feeling a lot better than I was at the beginning of the session. It's been really helpful to talk through that situation and practice reframing my thoughts. I don't think there's anything else I need to bring up today.

Therapist: I'm so glad to hear that you're feeling better, Jamie. You did some great work today, both in practicing self-compassion and in using the thought record to challenge some of those self-critical thoughts.

For homework this week, I'd like you to continue practicing self-compassion, especially in moments when you're feeling down or self-critical. Try to notice when those thoughts come up and consciously shift to a more understanding and supportive inner dialogue.

I also encourage you to keep using the thought record whenever you notice yourself getting stuck in negative thoughts. Remember, the goal is not to get rid of negative thoughts altogether, but to develop a more balanced and realistic perspective.

And finally, keep implementing your relapse prevention plan and wellness action plan. Those strategies will help you maintain your progress and manage any setbacks that come up.

Do you have any questions about the homework or anything else we discussed today?

Patient: No, I think it's pretty clear. I'll definitely keep working on the self-compassion and the thought records. And I'll try to stick to my relapse prevention and wellness plans too.

Therapist: Great. Remember, progress isn't always a straight line. There will be ups and downs, but what matters is that you keep moving forward and using your skills.

I want to acknowledge the incredible progress you've made over the course of our work together, Jamie. You've developed a whole toolbox of skills to manage your depression, from thought records to coping cards to self-compassion. You've shown a lot of courage and resilience in facing your challenges head-on.

I have no doubt that you have the tools and the strength to continue this work on your own. And remember, you can always come back for a booster session if you need a refresher or some extra support.

I'm so proud of you, Jamie, and I feel honored to have been a part of your journey. I wish you all the best as you continue on your path.

Patient: Thank you so much, Nova. I really appreciate all your help and support. I feel like I've learned so much and grown a lot through this process. I know I still have work to do, but I feel a lot more hopeful and equipped to handle whatever comes my way.

Therapist: You're very welcome, Jamie. It's been a pleasure working with you. Remember, you have the strength and the skills to keep moving forward, no matter what challenges arise. I have complete faith in you.

Take care of yourself, and don't hesitate to reach out if you need any support in the future.

Session Summary:
- Main topics discussed:
  - Reviewed Jamie's relapse prevention plan and wellness action plan
  - Discussed self-compassion and practiced reframing self-critical thoughts
  - Completed a thought record on a recent situation that triggered negative thoughts
  - Celebrated Jamie's progress and growth over the course of therapy
  - Discussed next steps for continuing to manage depression independently
- Techniques or exercises used:
  - Thought records for identifying and challenging cognitive distortions (continuing from previous sessions)
  - Coping cards for countering negative thoughts with more balanced and adaptive thoughts (continuing from previous sessions)
  - Relapse prevention planning for maintaining progress after therapy ends (continuing from previous sessions)
  - Wellness action planning for managing potential setbacks (continuing from previous sessions)
  - Self-compassion for managing self-critical thoughts (new)
- Homework assigned:
  - Continue practicing self-compassion, especially in moments of self-criticism or distress
  - Use thought records to challenge negative thoughts and develop a more balanced perspective
  - Implement relapse prevention plan and wellness action plan to maintain progress and manage setbacks
- Patient's progress, challenges, depression symptoms and important personal details:
  - Jamie has made significant progress in managing depression symptoms and building coping skills
  - Jamie is able to recognize and challenge cognitive distortions more effectively and use coping tools in daily life
  - Jamie still experiences bad days and setbacks, but is able to view them as learning opportunities and use skills to cope
  - Jamie is working on practicing self-compassion and reframing self-critical thoughts
- Core beliefs and intermediate beliefs:
  - Core belief: "I'm not good enough"
  - Intermediate beliefs: "I'm not worthy of love and acceptance," "If I don't find a job, I'm a failure"
  - Jamie is able to challenge these beliefs more effectively and recognize them as distortions
- Important information to carry forward to future sessions:
  - Continue reinforcing Jamie's progress and internalized skills
  - Address any setbacks or challenges that arise and help Jamie use skills to cope
  - Encourage Jamie to continue reaching out for support and using coping tools as needed
  - Celebrate Jamie's ongoing progress and growth, no matter how small
- Plan for the next session:
  - This was the final scheduled session, but Jamie is welcome to return for booster sessions as needed for additional support
  - Jamie will continue to implement relapse prevention plan and wellness action plan independently
  - Jamie will keep practicing self-compassion and using thought records to manage negative thoughts
  - Jamie will continue to build on the progress made in therapy and use the skills learned to manage depression in daily life
